intro: Solanum tuberosum f. pichuna, commonly known as the Pichuna potato, is a botanical variant of the common potato characterized by its unique morphological traits. It is native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes, where it thrives in cooler climates and well-drained soils. This variety is notable for its small, round tubers with a dark skin and a starchy, flavorful flesh. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, ovate leaves. Its cultivation is often associated with traditional farming practices in South American countries.
